facts.text: Petitioners are members of the Left Communist Party and were ordered to be detained along with others numbering 140 in all under r. 30(1)(b) of the Defence of India Rules by orders of the Governor of Kerala passed on December 29, 1964.

At that time the State of Kerala was being governed by virtue of the Proclamation of the President dated September 10, 1964, by which the President assumed to himself all functions of the Government of the State of Kerala and all powers vested in or exercisable by the Governor of that State.
A general election was going to be held in Kerala in the beginning of March 1965.
After the elections were over, the Left Communist Party emerged as the largest single party.

On March 4, 1965, the order of the Governor dated December 29, 1964 was cancelled and another order was made on the same date namely, March 4, 1965 by the Central Government in the name of the President ordering the detention of the petitioners under the Rules.
Both the order of cancellation and the new order of detention dated March 4, 1965 were served on the petitioners on March 6, 1965.
The petitions were made on March 15, 1965 but they reached this Court on April 12, 1965.

legal_issues.text: Whether the orders of detention dated March 4, 1965 are mala fide as they were passed to circumvent the possibility of the petitioners being released in case a party government came into power in the State of Kerala after the elections.
Whether there was no application of mind by the Government of India before passing the orders dated March 4, 1965, as 140 orders were passed on the same day.
Whether there was no material before the Central Government on March 4, 1965 on the basis of which the orders of detention could be passed.
Whether the cancellation of the detention orders dated December 29, 1964 on March 4, 1965 was illegal and whether there was no warrant for detention between March 4 and March 6, 1965.

petitioner_arguments.text: Orders of detention dated March 4, 1965 were mala fide to damage prospects of Left Communist Party in elections and later to prevent release after elections.
No application of mind when orders passed on December 29, 1964 and March 4, 1965.
No material before Central Government on March 4, 1965; file was with Government of Kerala.
If orders of December 29, 1964 were good, they could not be cancelled except by release; gap in detention between March 4 and March 6, 1965.

respondent_arguments.text: Denies mala fide; Government of India satisfied on materials that detention necessary to prevent acting prejudicial to defence of India, etc.
Question of detention under consideration for some time; satisfied re each individual; orders passed on same day after satisfaction.
File pertaining to activities of petitioners was before Government of India; satisfied from those papers.
Cancellation by President legal as Governor was agent; no need for release and re-arrest.

court_reasoning.text: Main points dealt with in K. Ananda Nambiar; only special points considered. Court examines only orders of March 4, 1965 as those in force.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Validity of detention on date of petition is what matters.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects mala fide; affidavit states satisfaction on materials for detention; denial sufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot say mala fide in face of affidavit.

court_reasoning.text: No force in no application of mind; under consideration for time; satisfied per individual despite same day.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Number of orders on one day does not prove no satisfaction.

court_reasoning.text: Material was before Central Govt; possible separate files; affidavit asserts papers were available and satisfaction reached.
Cancellation legal as Governor agent of President under Proclamation; Central Govt could decide to detain itself; no need for release/re-arrest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No illegality in withdrawal and fresh orders; detention under fresh order legal.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide effect between March 4-6 or precise timing of orders.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Detention under March 4 order legal when petition made.

holdings.text: Orders of detention dated March 4, 1965 are legal; not mala fide, application of mind and material present; cancellation and fresh orders valid.
Number of orders on same day does not indicate no application of mind.
Cancellation by President legal; no gap in detention requiring release.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. Ananda Nambiar v. Chief Secretary, Government of Madras and others
precedents_cited.relevance: Main points raised dealt with therein.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Godavari Shamrao Parulekar v. The State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: No need for empty formality of release and immediate re-arrest.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitions under Art. 32 for writ of habeas corpus for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Orders of detention passed under this rule.

outcome.summary: The Court dismissed the petitions holding that the detention under orders dated March 4, 1965 is legal, rejecting all contentions of mala fides, no application of mind, lack of material, and invalid cancellation. Noted inordinate delay in petitions reaching Court.

key_quotes.text: "It is well-settled that in dealing with a petition for habeas corpus the court has to see whether the detention on the date on which the application is made to the court is legal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope to current detention orders.

key_quotes.text: "We are not therefore prepared to accept from the simple fact that as many as 140 orders were passed on the same day there was no satisfaction of the Government of India with respect to each individual case."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects no application of mind argument.

key_quotes.text: "It was not necessary to carry out the empty formality of release from jail under the orders of cancellation and then to arrest the persons released immediately they came out of jail."
key_quotes.speaker: court
